[davido], [localtime://2006-12-14 13:46:16]
I'll take responsibility for the unconsideration. I believed that the original consideration was incorrect in recommending that the node be moved to [Meditations], and that the proper recommendation would be to assign it to the thread to which it was responding. Clearly it's not a SoPW, nor a stand-alone Meditation. It's a response.

I discussed it with [planetscape] because I wanted a second opinion, since I felt I was too close to the discussion to take action myself. However, I do want to say that my motives were not influenced by my proximity to the thread. I actually believe that reparenting it, while the right thing to do, will make it easier for people to downvote my own node in the thread, so if anything I have a disincentive, and yet I still feel it's the right thing to do. But I do want to apologize for the controversy, and will at least leave a note in the wiki in the future to document unconsiderations and the reason.

We see a lot of way-off-the-mark considerations, where a much better action is prevented from being voted on by the lingering errant consideration. Maybe this wasn't one of those cases, though I felt it was. But let's discuss for a moment what the proper course of action is in such cases where a good consideration is being prevented by a bad one lingering.

[tye], [localtime://2006-12-14 04:33:11]
It is a balance. Marring nodes with "unconsidered" footers isn't great but sometimes is probably the best route (for now). Leaving people (like me) wondering what happened to the previous consideration isn't great. Leaving a consideration up for a longer time means that I (and others) are likely to get a chance to see where the voting is going and not be left wondering as much -- so that is my preferred route in most cases.

Personally, I don't mind quickly unconsidering in many cases of a clearly bad consideration where the janitor sends a /msg to the considerer (clearly bad to me and clearly bad to most others). Title change considerations are the ones I most often see that I find clearly bad, and early unconsideration makes it more likely that someone else will provide a better new title suggestion if the node needs a new title but the consideration sucked. But recently I've seen a lot more considerations for trivial title changes (trying to improve a title instead of fix a broken title) and those I prefer to stay up a while so people have a chance to see the voting (and so I can see how the voting is going to guage trends) and see that the change isn't being made and see how many trivial requests are being thrown around, etc.

I wouldn't quickly unconsider a request to reap even if it seemed pretty clearly bad. The only drawback to waiting is that the node's author will get a few extra downvotes. There are more important benefits by giving everyone time.

And I will also confess to voting to reap [id://587931], but I did not unconsider it; that would have been, IMHO, a textbook case for leaving an unconsider footer to prevent it being immediately re-considered for the same reason.

But a footer doesn't prevent a node from being reconsidered for the same reason. Leaving the consideration up actually does. And if you are going to leave a footer, at least let the consideration exist long enough to justify a footer.

I'd just disallow unconsidering in less than 3 days if it weren't for "edit" considerations that get taken care of or mistake considerations.

If janitors discuss some action, then don't keep the rest of us in the dark. If it warranted discussion, then it warrants not being kept a secret. You don't have to have the conversation in the wiki, but at least leave a note that the discussion was had and the conclusions.

In this case, I'd not have rushed to remove the consideration even after some discussion. At least a discussion in public would have been better, so those visiting the site around the time of the consideration would have some chance to see that. And a lot of people would have had a chance to comment before someone's consideration was thrown away.

And a little further down that same section:

Please don't rush to consider a duplicate for reaping.

I find it frustrating enough when the general population considers something for reaping when they shouldn't. But I find it inexcusable when a [janitors|janitor] does it. We ought to know what's in our site's documentation. If we disagree with that, lets discuss and refine the policy. But until it's changed, let's execute it as written.

[tye], [localtime://2006-11-26 10:48:58]
I've repeatedly stated exactly why I think that trying to enforce a third party's copyright against the presumed infringement from a fourth party is a quite bad idea.

It is my experience that removing usernames and passwords is a mistake. Every case that I've seen has actually been for naught because each time it was discovered (which never surprised me) that the author had actually not created a security problem. But even if the author had, trying to unring the bell and pretend that the security problem had not been created isn't doing anyone a service. The only fix for such a situation is for the original password to be changed. So the best action is to notify the author and leave the node alone. It isn't like there aren't tons of cached copies around anyway, including ones [g0n] provides.

And we shouldn't be in the business of jumping to conclusions about whether or not a security problem was created.

I'm more in favor of removing personal information, at least temporarily, if it is suspected that it was posted with malice, though not without reservations. Posting your own password is a mistake you should face and deal with yourself. Someone else posting your personal information isn't such. A security problem really shouldn't be dealt with by minimizing it, leaking the password to only a presumed small part of the internet doesn't remove the need to change the password. Personal information often can't be changed and getting less spam is better than getting more spam so reducing the impact of such a leak may be warranted.

Un-work-safe language (etc.) is best dealt with by encouraging the author to change it or letting the community reap it. Beyond that, adding a "(NSFW)" tag to a title would be my preferred approach for quite a few reasons. It'd be nice to add such a tag in way that replies drop it automatically, since the "Re:"-handling code does drop certain things, but I'm not sure that'll work in many cases and won't pursue it further at this point.

I've seen one or two of these, and had to click somewhere else sharpish.

As to links to pirated content, such nodes seem to be routinely edited to remove the link, and in my view rightly so, but whether we should do this is not stated anywhere.

[davido], [localtime://2006-11-09 18:24:27]
A note to [janitors] all: Please do be active in voting on considerations, even if you're often less active in performing edits. You've been dubbed [Janitors|Janitor] because the [gods] believed in your wisdom. Sometimes the best wisdom can be imparted by actively voting. This is especially true of 'keep' votes. So many simply think, "Hmm, sounds good to me..." and vote "edit" even if a prudent [Janitors|janitor] would assert that the best course of action is to leave it alone. Your 'keep' votes might be the only ones out there. But your opinion matters significantly.

I see on the [id://28877|ntc] list nodes considered for changing PRE to CODE tags, retitling, marking off-topic, and various other issues. Some of those issues are more serious, and easier to fix, such as changing out errant PRE tags in favor of CODE tags. Others may be less compelling. When voting (and subsequently either acting or not acting), ask yourself if what you're doing matters enough for you to tamper with a node. Often it does matter enough. Sometimes it doesn't. In the US, they say a person is innocent until proven guilty beyond reasonable doubt. Perhaps we should look at the threshold for our intervention with a similarly conservative perspective. Leet's not rush to convict a node if it might not be necessary to do so. Remember the excellent counsel given in [id://459456]. I would take it a step further and suggest that we, in addition to being [janitors], have a responsibility to be teachers of the ways of the Monastery. The /msg system is our tool to that end, along with our examples, and our working with [SiteDocClan] to maintain accurate and helpful documentation for newcomers. We should be sending helpful /msg's to posters, and to those making considerations alike. Such minor corrections in individuals' courses will help to maintain the aggregate course of the big ship. (Sorry for the metaphor; Monasteries don't have physical courses, much less websites, so I had to come up with another object.)

So to summarize my long-winded thoughts: Vote on considerations. Don't be afraid to vote 'keep'. When you feel that a consideration misses the mark somehow, /msg the person who considered the node. When you feel that a post should have been formatted or posted differently, /msg the author regardless of whether or not any janitorial work gets done. Keep it kind and helpful. Teach. Enjoy!

[davido], [localtime://2006-11-04 02:16:00]
Ok, I saw the wiki, saw what happened, saw [tye]'s response, and felt the issue had been handled. When I spoke with [planetscape], it seemed she understood, and I was satisfied that she had a better handle on what's appropriate now. My own reluctance to jump into the wiki on this has nothing to do with a lack of support for [tye]'s position, but rather, that I just felt he expressed himself clearly enough to put the issue to rest. But I understand how [tye|you] feel like you've been the only champion of the cause.

So let me state my position on edits (which has evolved somewhat over the past year or two, and I'll try to point out those areas where I've evolved):

  • Consideration votes are recommendations only. A prudent steward would listen to the recommendations, and weigh them with his/her elevated experience and understanding on how things are supposed to be done around here. 50 edit votes doesn't mean it's right if the consideration is asking us to do something that we simply don't do. It's ok to not act on an affirmative consideration vote. We have been given this stewardship because the [gods] felt we had an elevated understanding / experience. Let's not be afraid to do what's right rather than what's popular.
  • Just like it's ok to decline to take action on a consideration, it's also ok to take action even when there hasn't been a consideration. It usually doesn't hurt to wait, but sometimes it's preferable to just get it over with when you know it's needed. An example of this might be when a node has been considered for code tags, and while you're working on the code tags you realize there are also a bunch of pre tags forcing long lines. ...clean that up while you're there too, rather than waiting for a second consideration.
  • There are lots of [janitors]: When in doubt, leave it alone for someone else to act on, or to not act on.
  • Resist the urge to participate just because you want to use your powers. Ask yourself, would it hurt anything if I left this node alone? Am I just jumping in because I can, or am I really doing this because I should?
  • Never ever under any circumstances alter text. I take this to also mean never linkify (though it may be ok to fix a link that's broken, if the author cannot be contacted or doesn't respond to contact attempts).
  • Restrict edits to: code tags, formatting to match the OP's intended layout, removal of formatting that damages page rendering (such as really wide pre blocks), retitling when absolutely necessary to protect navagability, addition of readmore tags when it's blatantly obvious that they're needed. When I say "formatting to match the OP's intended layout", this is easy to determine when looking at the editor's display of a node, because in that display you can see exactly how the OP typed his post. Chances are good those posts where everything is all run together actually have neat and tidy formatting in the way the node was entered. It just lacked the markup to cause that formatting to render.
  • Reparenting is ok rarely, but probably best to wait until there's been a consideration, and some [janitorial] discussion first. That's probably the tool we should be using the least, but there are times when it's the right thing to do.
  • Tread as lightly as possible. If a minor formatting edit gets the job done, don't dive into a major edit.
  • Here's where I've evolved: I don't feel it's usually necessary to leave a janitorial attribution. In other words, unless you think people actually need to know you've touched a node, don't leave your tag-line at the bottom. I used to add such lines religiously. But doing so is altering the text of a node, even though it's not the same as putting words in someone's mouth. And we're just not here to plop our names into every node we can. We're here to quietly fix problems and fade into the background again. An exception to this sentiment is with retitling. There, it's good to put the attribution at the bottom of the node along with the original title. This is mostly as an aid to the author.
  • Contrary to what I just said, it's probably ok to leave attributions on nodes we've edited which were authored by Anonymous Monk. Why? Because there's no way to /msg him explaining how to improve. So the attribution will concisely let him know (if he's watching) that his post was edited... so that hopefully he'll take the initiative of trying to learn what to do next time so it won't be necessary. Another situation where it's probably wise to leave an attribution at the bottom is when a node is reparented, so that people can see where it came from, and how it came to reside where it is after the reparenting.
  • And lastly, always /msg the author letting him know what you did, and why. If at all possible, seek to get the author to fix things himself before you (we) take action. Sending a /msg to someone asking them nicely to fix something will often have the proper effect. If you've tried that already, and it hasn't panned out, do the edit, and then /msg them again letting them know what you did, why, and where to read to learn to do it correctly next time.

Ok, I guess that about sums it up, except that I'm sure I missed a bunch of topics. The important points are: We should be minimalists, we should never alter text, and we should be the voices of reason even when the mob insists that we sway to their demands. If disastrous nodes can be made to appear legible, and otherwise our presence is barely noticed, except by the author who got a kind and educational /msg from us, we've done our jobs right, imho.

Oh, another thought... When you see lousy, improper, poorly worded, un-actionable, vague, or otherwise deficient considerations, /msg the considerer to let him know why it's bad. Everyone likes to help out, but in their eagerness to help, they often present us with considerations that aren't helpful at all. It'll keep happening unless we one-by-one help these moderators to understand where they can improve. I've made it a practice to vote 'keep' on any consideration that isn't right on target.
